text:
This is an 80 yo female w/PMed Hx of CAD, CABG, DMwho came from the heb
   Reb with SOB.  At Heb Reb she had 1 week of fevers and altered mental
   status, her alter MS coincided with the administration of baclofen and
   dilaudid
 these were D/Ced.  On [**3-8**] her 02 SAT was 80% on RA and 90%
   on 3 liters; this initiated her transfer to [**Hospital1 54**].  In the EW her temp
   was 100.8, 163/73,101, 18 99% on 3 liters.  An EKG showed 1mm ST
   depressions in V4-5, BNP was 4005 and her CXR showed multifocal
   pneumonia.
    Pt ruled out for MI this admission. TTE showed diastolic dysfunction.
   Continues to struggle with hypoxia/resp distress with absolutely no
   reserve..  Supplemental O2 is maxed out at 95% high flow neb with
   frequent episodes tachypnea to 40
s. Pt restless at times. Team would
   like to get chest CT and bronchial lavage but feel she would need to be
   intubated for either of these procedures. They plan to insert A-line
   today.
   Pt Complains of chronic back and neck pain. Receives PRN Percocet and
   TID neurontin 300mg for the complaints of pain.
   Access has been an issue today. Her midline was phlebitic and needed to
   be d/c
d. Warm compresses applied Q4hr. I was not able to insert new
   PIV> IVT came and got second PIV placed and later came to insert PICC
   in left AC.
   Pneumonia, bacterial, hospital acquired (non-VAP)
   Assessment:
   Action:
   Response:
   Plan:
   Heart failure (CHF), Diastolic, Acute
   Assessment:
   Pt
s vital signs stable on lisinopril 40mg PO QD as well as lopressor
   25mg PO BID for rate/BP control
   Action:
   Checking BP on lower right arm due to phlebitis on upper right and new
   PICC in left AC
   Response:
   BP is stable. Will hold off on diuresis for now because pt is
   co,mplaining of thirst and creatinine is slightly higher today.
   Plan:
   Consider diuresis later if needed. Continue to follow labs/vital signs
   closely.
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
   Assessment:
   Pt complains of left neck, shoulder, back pain constantly.
   Action:
   Gets slight relief from one percocet and one Tylenol given twice this
   shift. Also pt repositioned and given back rub with increased comfort.
   Response:
   Slight improvement in comfort from percocet, Tylenol and position
   change with back rub.
   Plan:
   Continue pain relief measures as tolerated.
   Numerous family members in to see pt today (she has six children) I
   have asked them to  limit visit time and numbers because pt will not
   stop wanting to interact with them and becomes hypoxic easily while
   they visit. She also has coughing jags while she tries to talk and
   desaturates easily. Family seems to understand and comply with my
   wishes but with so many here it is difficult for her to rest. We will
   need to continue to request that they limit pt stimulation.
